You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 728, 636]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 905, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 683, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the balancing of a metre ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 579, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 129, 895, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 316, 534, 333]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 346, 146, 364]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 346, 881, 363]]<|/det|> • Place the metre ruler on the pivot at the 50.0 cm mark with its scale facing upwards. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 361, 789, 378]]<|/det|> • Place the object Q with its centre on the metre ruler at the 90.0 cm mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 393, 771, 411]]<|/det|> Record the distance \(y\) from the centre of Q to the 100.0 cm end of the ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 425, 920, 443]]<|/det|>
y = .................................................... cm [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 146, 473]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 456, 631, 473]]<|/det|> • Place a load P of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 470, 920, 504]]<|/det|> • Adjust the position of P so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 181, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 517, 920, 550]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(x\) from the centre of P to the zero end of the ruler. Record the weight \(P\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 550]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 562, 181, 581]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 848, 581]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps above, using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}, 4.0 \text{N}, 5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 594, 920, 628]]<|/det|> Record all the values of \(P\) and \(x\) in Table 1.1. Ensure that the position of object Q on the metre ruler does **not** change. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 641, 539, 658]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 667, 616, 819]]<|/det|>
\(P/\mathrm {N}\)\(x/\mathrm {cm}\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 821, 920, 839]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 332, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 603, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 128, 863, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 386, 532, 405]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 144, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 418, 645, 437]]<|/det|> Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 480, 146, 499]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 480, 181, 499]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 480, 920, 514]]<|/det|> Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the hot water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 920, 560]]<|/det|> Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 144, 846, 650]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 666, 532, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 698, 144, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 698, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
Draw a line across the ray-trace sheet supplied, approximately in the middle. Label the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 728, 171, 745]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 728, 920, 760]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block, largest face down, with the straight side on the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\) and the curved side below the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 758, 171, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 758, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
Draw round the outline of the block. Label the ends of the straight side of the block \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 789, 171, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 789, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and draw the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\). Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 820, 175, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 820, 621, 838]]<|/det|>
Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 836, 920, 855]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 787, 91]]<|/det|>
Draw the line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 475, 106]]<|/det|>
Place the paper on the pin board.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 895, 120]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 918, 165]]<|/det|>
Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1 to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 918, 197]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 524, 214]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 460, 229]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and the pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 771, 245]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 243, 564, 261]]<|/det|>
Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 260, 920, 279]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 787, 828, 807]]<|/det|>
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this question booklet between pages 8 and 9.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the change in resistance of a lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 420, 135]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 285, 166]]<|/det|>
· a power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 384, 182]]<|/det|>
· a low-voltage filament lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 255, 197]]<|/det|>
· an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 255, 212]]<|/det|>
· a voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 213, 303, 228]]<|/det|>
· connecting wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 702, 259]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the change in resistance of the lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) , where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp and \(I\) is the current in the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 485, 381]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 217, 411]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 440, 442]]<|/det|>
· draw a diagram of the circuit used

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 801, 458]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation, including how to change the current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 920, 489]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 489, 616, 504]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
# BLANK PAGE
